image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

profileText: A Representative from Iowa; born in Little Falls, Herkimer County, N.Y., March 14, 1923; graduated from St. Mary's Academy New York, N.Y.; attended Southern Methodist University of Dallas, Dallas, Tex., 1945-1947; United States Navy, 1942-1946, United States Naval Reserve, 1947-1954; assistant division manager with George D. Barnard Co., Dallas, Tex., 1947; became a grain and livestock farmer, 1948; chair, Mills County Republican Central committee, 1956-1964; member of the State house of representatives, 1960-1966; elected as a Republican to the Ninetieth and to the three succeeding Congresses (January 3, 1967-January 3, 1975); unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1974 to the Ninety-fourth Congress; deputy administrator, United States Department of Agriculture, 1975-1977; president of a consulting firm in Washington, D.C., 1977-1987; died on August 27, 2003, in Council Bluffs, Iowa; interment in Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, Va.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Ralph Nader Congress Project. Citizens Look at Congress: William J. Scherle, Republican Representative from Iowa. Washington, D. C.: Grossman Publishers, 1972.

researchRecord.name: 1969-1971, 0.25 linear foot.
researchRecord.description: The papers include Congressman William Scherle's reports to his constituents in the 7th Iowa Congressional District.

researchRecord.name: 1970, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: Includes a letter from William J. Scherle to Paul Engle written on June 19, 1970. In the letter, William Scherle declines an invitation to a reception.

researchRecord.name: In the W.H. Goodrich Papers, 1966-1977, 1.5 linear feet.
In the Lester L. Kluever Papers, 1949-1970, 6 linear feet.
In the Wiley Mayne Papers, 1966-1974, 118 feet.
researchRecord.description: Correspondents include William J. Scherle. A finding aid is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the Arthur A. Neu Papers, 1965-1979, 26 feet.
researchRecord.description: Correspondents include William J. Scherle. A finding aid is available in the repository.
